title: 108_s1451
content: The Act is titled the "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act." It amends the findings section of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. The Congress finds that youth who are homeless or run away without parental permission are at risk of serious health and behavioral problems due to lack of resources. They urgently need temporary shelter and linguistically appropriate services. The Federal Government has a responsibility to address this interstate issue. The Federal Government is responsible for developing a national reporting system to address the issues of runaway and homeless youth. This includes providing care services, opportunities for education and employment, and improving coordination between federal programs serving this population. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to change the heading to "Basic Center" and include testing for sexually transmitted diseases at the request of youth. An obsolete provision related to certain allotments is repealed. SEC. 104 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act repeals an obsolete provision related to certain allotments. SEC. 105 changes "juveniles" to "youth" in eligibility provisions. SEC. 106 recognizes state law relating to capacity limitations on eligible runaway and homeless youth centers. Section 312(b)(2)(A) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include a provision for higher maximum compliance with licensure requirements for child and youth serving facilities. Additionally, there is a mention of maternity group homes in the following section. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include maternity group homes as eligible facilities and define them as transitional living arrangements for pregnant or parenting youth to learn parenting skills and promote long-term economic stability. Maternity group homes provide pregnant or parenting youth with parenting skills and promote long-term economic independence for the well-being of their children. Limited extension of 540-day shelter eligibility period for youth under 18 years old in a program under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. Youth can remain in the program until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the end of the 540-day period. SEC. 109 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to involve McKinney-Vento school district liaisons in providing educational services to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 110 establishes a coordination agreement for Part B of the plan. SEC. 110 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to coordinate services with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons for educational services. SEC. 111 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to develop a plan for proper referral of homeless youth to various services. SEC. 112 focuses on coordinating programs. SEC. 112 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to ensure coordination of programs and services for homeless youth by consulting the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority, and SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment relating to demonstration projects. SEC. 114 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act by removing the word "temporary" from section 344. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision related to a study. SEC. 116 sets an age limit of not more than 18 years for homeless youth seeking shelter. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations for the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifying funding amounts for fiscal years 2004-2008 and adjusting the allocation percentages for parts B and E. SEC. 118 requires a report on strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years. SEC. 119 calls for a study on housing services and strategies. SEC. 119 requires a study on housing services and strategies for youth exiting programs funded under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. The study aims to report on long-term housing outcomes, available services, placement strategies, and models to prevent future homelessness. SEC. 389 restricts the use of funds in distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. Any entity receiving funds must account for separate use of funds. SEC. 201 amends findings in the Missing Children's Assistance Act. The Congress acknowledges the grave danger faced by abducted children, the risks of physical harm and exploitation, the lack of resources for search efforts, the need for cooperation among law enforcement agencies, and the role of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children as a national resource center. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children works in partnership with various government agencies to find missing children and prevent child victimization. It operates a national and worldwide network, connecting with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Scotland Yard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, INTERPOL headquarters, and others to transmit images and information to law enforcement. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children partners with government agencies to locate missing children and prevent child victimization by connecting with missing children clearinghouses worldwide to transmit information to law enforcement. The Missing Children's Assistance Act is amended to authorize appropriations for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children until 2008. This is part of the reauthorization of programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act.
